Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Undergraduate Research in Musical Acoustics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports two related projects within the context of musical acoustics. The two projects represent complex problems involving energy transfer in metal structures. The specific goals are to understand the stick-slip excitation mechanism of idiophones and to determine how structural vibrations affect the sound of brass wind instruments. Studies of the stick-slip excitation of idiophones will be performed using electronic speckle pattern interferometery, laser Doppler vibrometry and recordings of the acoustic field resulting from the vibrations. The results of the experimental research will be compared to a computer model that includes the dynamic effects, as well as the effects attributable to the size of the region of interaction between the instrument and the driver. Studies of structural vibrations of brass wind instruments will involve both optical and acoustic measurements. Previous work has shown that the vibration of the walls of the instrument contribute substantially to the sound produced by the instrument, and that this contribution is not due to direct radiation of the vibrating metal into the surrounding air. This research will lead to an understanding of the mechanism through which the vibrating metal contributes to the sound field.

This work involves undergraduate students, particularly women, in original research. While the systems under study involve musical instruments, the research centers on studying basic physical phenomena which are not unique to musical acoustics. The work will contribute to the understanding of physical systems while providing undergraduate students the opportunity to be involved in original scientific research through a subject they find fascinating.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work supported by this grant involved collaborating with undergraduate students to understand the basic physics of selected musical instruments. The primary goal was to involve undergraduate students in original scientific research and introduce them to the excitement and challenge that will result in a life dedicated to scientific pursuits. The specific scientific goals were to understand the physics of selected musical instruments, with an emphasis on the inherently interesting physics as well as the applicability to other scientific and engineering problems. Four investigations were completed within the context of this grant. Two projects involving acoustic energy transfer in metal structures, one addressing the energy transfer from transverse to longitudinal motion in taut wires, and one addressing a misunderstanding of a demonstration of the effects of photon momentum.

(1) It is well known that when a static object is in contact with a moving piece of metal, such as when a brake pad is in contact with the rotor of a disk brake, the two parts alternately stick and slip across the surface of the metal. This stick-slip process can produce vibrations in the metal that result an audible sound. There is a widely accepted theory describing this process that predicts the vibrational pattern of the structure, which determines what sound is produced. The students investigated this process in the context of the Himalayan singing bowl, which is a metal bowl played by rubbing a stick around the edge. Their work resulted in a deeper understanding of how longitudinal vibrations in metal structures can excite bending waves. These bending waves produce the sound, which can be pleasing, as in the case of a Himalayan singing bowl, or annoying, as in the case of the squeal of disk brakes. The research revealed that, contrary to what is commonly believed, when longitudinal standing waves are driven by stick-slip motion the driving mechanism is not centered on a node of the bending wave. This displacement of the driver from the part of the structure that is not moving is motivating further research, with the goal of determining which physical parameters determine the magnitude of the displacement. The results of this work are helping to explain the physics of this popular musical instrument, but they can also be directly applied toward ongoing efforts to suppress environmental noise resulting from stick-slip interactions such as brake squeal and the sound that train wheels make when rounding a curve.

(2) The interaction between vibrating air and the walls that contain the air is a complex problem of broad interest. The students investigated this interaction in the context of the modern trumpet, which is a case where structural vibrations are known to interact with the internal pressure wave, affecting the radiated sound. Several possible explanations have been posited to account for the audible effects that the vibrating walls of a trumpet have on the sound produced by the instrument, but to date the only theory that appears to adequately explain the data was developed in the context of this research. The results of the work supported by this grant have demonstrated that the coupling between wall vibrations and the internal air column of flaring ducts is due in part to the existence of longitudinal modes of vibration in the duct. This interaction will occur in any situation where there is flowing air inside a flaring duct, be it a trumpet bell or an industrial air handling system.

 (3) The theoretical relationship between transverse waves in taut wires and the longitudinal waves they induce was predicted in the 1940s but had not been shown to be accurate. Although researchers have used this theory extensively over the past 70 years, experimental confirmation has been lacking. The students confirmed this theory in the context of a piano string, where the induced longitudinal waves produce a sound known as a phantom partial. The work has direct application to the synthesis of piano sounds, but it also impacts any situation where wires are stretched between two rigid supports.

 (4) It is well known that photons carry momentum, and one of the classic classroom demonstrations of this involves using a common photoflash to produce a sound from an orchestral cymbal. The students supported by this grant showed that, contrary to popular belief (and the information found on the CERN website), the sound is not produced by the presence of photon momentum, but instead by thermal expansion of the metal. This work is primarily applicable to the pedagogy of teaching physics.
